Line 75: Line 75:
===Athletics===
===Athletics===
  +
[[File:Fightingscot.png|25px|thumb|right|Fighting Scot]]
* '''History:''' Wooster's athletic history dates back to its first baseball team, in 1880, which played only one game, losing 12-2 to [[Kenyon College]]. The football program was established in 1889; over its first two seasons, the team won all seven games it played, by a total score of 306-4. Included was a 64-0 victory at [[Ohio State University|Ohio State]] on November 1, 1890, in the Buckeyes' first-ever home football game<ref>http://www.hmdb.org/marker.asp?marker=12442</ref>. Shortly thereafter, intercollegiate sports were banned by the College President.<ref>http://athletics.wooster.edu/fb/archives/history.php</ref> After varsity athletics returned in 1901, Wooster became an early member of the [[Ohio Athletic Conference]] (OAC). In 1983, Wooster (along with the rest of the [[Five Colleges of Ohio|Ohio Five]]) broke away from the OAC to form the [[North Coast Athletic Conference]] (NCAC). The NCAC, which competes at the non-scholarship [[NCAA Division III|Division III]] level of the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]], was founded primarily on the principle of offering women equal opportunity to participate in varsity sports<ref>http://www.northcoast.org/history.html</ref>. In its first season of competition, 1984-85, the NCAC sponsored 21 sports, eleven for men and ten for women. Women's softball was added in 1998, giving the NCAC its current 22 sports. Wooster fields varsity athletic teams in all 22 of these sports.
* '''History:''' Wooster's athletic history dates back to its first baseball team, in 1880, which played only one game, losing 12-2 to [[Kenyon College]]. The football program was established in 1889; over its first two seasons, the team won all seven games it played, by a total score of 306-4. Included was a 64-0 victory at [[Ohio State University|Ohio State]] on November 1, 1890, in the Buckeyes' first-ever home football game<ref>http://www.hmdb.org/marker.asp?marker=12442</ref>. Shortly thereafter, intercollegiate sports were banned by the College President.<ref>http://athletics.wooster.edu/fb/archives/history.php</ref> After varsity athletics returned in 1901, Wooster became an early member of the [[Ohio Athletic Conference]] (OAC). In 1983, Wooster (along with the rest of the [[Five Colleges of Ohio|Ohio Five]]) broke away from the OAC to form the [[North Coast Athletic Conference]] (NCAC). The NCAC, which competes at the non-scholarship [[NCAA Division III|Division III]] level of the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]], was founded primarily on the principle of offering women equal opportunity to participate in varsity sports<ref>http://www.northcoast.org/history.html</ref>. In its first season of competition, 1984-85, the NCAC sponsored 21 sports, eleven for men and ten for women. Women's softball was added in 1998, giving the NCAC its current 22 sports. Wooster fields varsity athletic teams in all 22 of these sports.
